Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Situation2: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Story: I glanced at the clock above my register, feeling the minutes slip away. My boyfriend had texted me earlier, reminding me that tonight was our only free evening together before I left for a week-long work trip. He wanted to cook dinner, watch a movie, just be together—something we hadn’t done in ages. I promised I’d be home on time. But now, as I scanned groceries for the few customers trickling in, my manager approached and asked if I could stay late. Someone had called out, and the evening shift was short-handed. I knew the expectation: process every transaction carefully, keep the line moving, don’t make mistakes. My heart pounded as I weighed the request. If I stayed, I’d disappoint my boyfriend and break my promise. If I left, I’d let down my team and risk my reputation at work. The beep of the scanner sounded louder than usual, echoing the tension inside me as I tried to decide which role I owed more to tonight.
